p: As proposed in the “ecological plaque hypothesis”, a carious lesion develops under changed environmental conditions, producing a corresponding disturbance to the stability of the resident microflora [ 1]. Changes occur when the frequency of fermentable dietary carbohydrate intake is increased. In such a situation, the biofilm spends more time at low pH, allowing Streptococcus mutans to proliferate at the expense of the resident community. S. mutans contributes to the lowering of the pH and the growth of acidogenic species at the expense of the resident microflora [ 2, 3]. This breakdown disrupts the de- and remineralization in teeth, pushing the equilibrium toward demineralization and tooth cavities. Candida albicans can appear in cariogenic biofilm when bonded to S. mutans, thus increasing the virulence of the biofilm and resulting in severe and recurrent caries in early childhood [ 4] and in salivary disorders [ 5].
